children.text: [Casey Kaufman (INTERVIEWER)]: Today is September 20th, 2019, and we're in Hodges Library in
the production room of the studio on UT Campus in Knoxville.
Today, we're going to be interviewing Seemona Whaley and Daniel Whaley,
who live here in Knoxville, and I just want to start
off by thanking you both for coming in today.
You are actually the first people that we're interviewing through this entire project.
And we're, over the next three years,
we're going to hopefully be interviewing many more people,
casting a wide net across the people who were involved in or impacted by
the Chimney Tops II Wildfires that took place in Gatlinburg in Sevier County,
and impacted all of East Tennessee.
And we just thank you so much for being here and your willingness
to work through this with us today and sharing your story.
[Seemona Whaley (NARRATOR 1)]: It's our pleasure.
[Daniel Whaley (NARRATOR 2)]: It's our pleasure, yeah.
[INTERVIEWER]: So we'll start off, you've already done this, but we'll start off by just having you state your names,
and telling us a little bit about your life in Gatlinburg.
When did you move there?
Tell us about your past history in the City of Gatlinburg.
[NARRATOR 2]: Well, my family is originally from the Greenbrier area,
so there's a couple of cabins up top of Greenbrier,
where the original chimney,
I think Pinkney Whaley.
So if you ask anybody or anybody asks you what vein of Whaley you are from,
it was a gentleman named Pinkney.
The original fire place is still
there with a couple of hiking cabins that are connected to it.
There old cantilever barns still up there so,
I grew up knowing Greenbrier since I was a baby.
And although I lived in Knoxville,
our family was up there,
so Gatlinburg is always been a special place for me and my family.
But I raised here,
I left early after my education,
and went to different places in the Southeast, Memphis, Atlanta.
I ended up in Miami, where I met her.
After we left Miami,
we had a vacation home up here in Gatlinburg,
and we decided to
sell everything in Miami and come back to East Tennessee in the mountains.
We lived there, Gatlinburg,
I guess for four or five years.
[NARRATOR 1]: From 2013.
I'm Seemona Whaley,
and prior to moving to Gatlinburg,
I lived in Florida, South Florida.
And after I met Daniel,
we vacationed in Gatlinburg,
almost every year, and finally,
moved there in 2013.
And then we left in 2017, so four years.
[INTERVIEWER]: So tell me about your occupation.
I know you were a teacher at Pi Beta Phi Elementary,
and you kind of travel all over the place. So tell me a little bit about that.
[NARRATOR 1]: Yeah. After about six months living in Gatlinburg,
I decided to get my paraprofessional license,
and became an assistant teacher for third grade at Pi Beta Phi Elementary School,
and it was the best decision.
Great way to get involved with the community,
and just getting to know from the bottom up.
[NARRATOR 2]: While I was going to the University of Tennessee
back in the '80s,
early '80s, I started working for Miller's Department Store
as a store detective during the '82 World's Fair,
if anybody remembers that.
And over the years, I went to work for Federated Department Store,
it's now Macy's in their security departments, loss prevention.
Went on to work for Home Depot and that's in South Florida as
a Director of Loss Prevention and Operations,
and then came back to East Tennessee four or five years ago
and contract work for different retailers all over the country.
Then currently, the Global Director of Loss Prevention for Regal Cinemas.
So we have 200 cinemas in Europe and 550 cinemas here in the US.
I'm over their security departments now.
[INTERVIEWER]: When you were in Gatlinburg, I know you were involved in the community and other ways.
Can you tell me a little bit about that?
[NARRATOR 1]: Yes. Actually, we were members of the First Baptist Church of Gatlinburg,
and that afforded us to be...I was able to do like in the summers to
the vacation Bible school with the kids
and Mother's Day Out and just getting to know everyone.
Also, just being a part of the school,
we were, we did like the chili cook offs and all those things,
and just a lot of fun.
That community is really close-knit.
And I think everyone, there's not one event that occurred
there that the community as a whole,
you didn't have to belong to an organization.
They just showed up.
[NARRATOR 2]: I was on the road all the time,
so she was the lifeline. You know, she knew more.
I'm, of course, rooted in that community up there,
but she knew more people than I did.
But I was home for church on Sundays and got to know a lot of people up there,
but she knows everybody.
[NARRATOR 1]: I talk more than you.
[NARRATOR 2]: Yeah.
[INTERVIEWER]: So we're going start going into a little bit of detail
about the days leading up to the wildfires and your experience during the fire.
I'll start off by just asking you,
can you recall any of your memories of
the days leading up to the wildfires and the day before?
[NARRATOR 1]: Oh yeah.
From the front of our home,
we lived in Chalet Village,
and we lived right next door to one of the pools.
So our driveway came up to their parking lot.
And from that parking lot,
looking out towards the mountains,
there were two plumes of smoke,
almost, I would say a good week,
week and a half.
They were not ominous, I mean, they just...
We knew it was on the news.
We knew that there was a fire there.
There were signs that obviously talked about smoke,
and the danger, and all that.
But it was business as usual in Gatlinburg,
and, you know, we went to school,
went to work, and no one expected anything like that to happen.
So yeah, it was business as usual.
[NARRATOR 2]: I was traveling for a week,
home office for a week,
and that week, I was actually home.
To her point, you can see the plumes of smoke way off in the distance.
If I had to...there was almost the denial even up to
the night of the fire when it came into Gatlinburg.
It's like "No way."
[NARRATOR 1]: This can't happen.
[NARRATOR 2]: "Can't happen." So you see the smoke,
you really don't think anything about it.
[NARRATOR 1]: And it wasn't in the community at that time,
not like, it wasn't smoky, you couldn't even smell it.
So for us, it was just so far away, you know.
[INTERVIEWER]: At what point did you become concerned?
[NARRATOR 2]: About 8:30 that evening when you saw the flames.
Candidly, I was in denial.
I was ready to get the water hose out and start
soaking those those leaves around the house that night,
which was looking back on it,
it was just absolutely ridiculous thought.
But we were getting texts and phone calls from some of our friends
in Gatlinburg saying, "Get out." [NARRATOR 1]: Well, Martha.
[NARRATOR 2]: Yeah, we had friends that saying it,
and we were saying, "We're okay, come on up.
It's no way it could get up here."
We were way up near over Gatlinburg.
[NARRATOR 1]: Well, that day also, the day that the evacuation occurred,
I had, I worked half a day at the school,
so I had gone home already.
Our son, Pearson was still at school.
And about, I guess around 11 o'clock,
I received a phone call from the teacher that I was an assistant to,
Sarah Reagan, and she said,
"You need to come and get Pearson,
we're evacuating the school,
and they're going to take the kids to Gatlinburg-Pittman High School."
And I lived right up the mountain.
We lived on Ski Mountain,
so I got in my car, drove down.
Officer Myers was there,
and he let me in,
and I got Pearson.
They were signing children out.
And at that point, sorry.
[NARRATOR 2]: I was still in denial,
I had no idea.
[NARRATOR 1]: It looked worse down by the school.
[NARRATOR 2]: Smoky.
[NARRATOR 1]: Than up where we were. It looked like a volcano had erupted,
and there was ashes falling.
[INTERVIEWER]: So you took your son to the high school?
[NARRATOR 1]: I actually got him before they took the kids to the high school.
And then the parents that didn't make it in time before they were able to evacuate,
the kids had to go to the high school.
[NARRATOR 2]: So you came home.
Yeah.
We came back up the mountain.
[INTERVIEWER]: This is about the afternoon?
[NARRATOR 1]: Yes. So as we're driving up the mountain,
the air is clearing.
So I thought, okay, it's just going to blow away. It will be fine.
[NARRATOR 2]: So it starts getting dark, and then...
[NARRATOR 1]: It was like night at the school when I went to get him in the middle of the day.
But the time we got back up to the house which is at a higher elevation.
It was okay again,
a little, you know, smoky but bright compared to by the school.
[NARRATOR 2]: Down in the city.
[NARRATOR 1]: I saw that. Go ahead.
[INTERVIEWER]: Let me go back a little bit. When you were at the school,
picking up Pearson, what was the feeling,
general feeling like among the teachers?
[NARRATOR 1]: The teachers were amazing.
They were calm, they kept the kids calm, which was surprising.
The children were sitting in the hallway waiting for their parents.
Everybody was there in the school,
It was just calm.
Outside of the school, you had parents, just...
You can just imagine the panic.
But even then, I think everyone kind of kept their cool.
No one was being irate.
They were all following instructions.
And but it was outside.
The chaos outside was not reflected on the inside.
It was, it was quite something.
[INTERVIEWER]: So you headed back home,
up the mountain. Later that evening.
Tell me about what transpired.
[NARRATOR 1]: We lost power.
[NARRATOR 2]: We lost power. And it's getting dark.
[NARRATOR 1]: And the wind had, I told you before,
I had experienced several hurricanes in Florida.
And I thought to myself,
"This is like having a hurricane."
The trees are like noodles.
They're literally just swaying.
And I thought, "Good gosh, this, this is Tennessee.
We don't get, you know, these winds up here."
And I guess the winds are what knocked out the power.
So we had no power. It was cold, you know.
I mean, you can imagine but the air was not so cold.
It was just the strangest thing.
I was wearing Uggs and I had on my sweatpants and I remember going, "Gosh, I'm hot."
It's the middle of, it's cold out and I'm really hot.
And because of the winds,
I went outside and moved our cars because I
thought a tree is going to fall down on the car and it's going to be smashed.
So I moved the cars and I came back inside and just thought, oh you know, it's kind of nice.
Winds whistling outside, it's going to be a storm.
And again, in denial.
Mister, I'm going to get the garden hose.
[NARRATOR 2]: Yeah, you know, well I'll get the garden hose, soak everything down a little bit.
Then there's a Buckberry Lodge sits down below us probably,
I mean, a half-mile.
[NARRATOR 1]: Yeah.
[NARRATOR 2]: Two streets below where our home was.
[NARRATOR 1]: We could see it from the back deck.
[NARRATOR 2]: And then you saw the flames and then it was like mmm, yeah...
[NARRATOR 1]: At that time, remember Martha had called.
[NARRATOR 2]: She did the texting.
[NARRATOR 1]: She texted me and she said,
"They've just told us that I need to get out of my house.
So I'm gonna go to the shelter."
I said, "Oh, Martha, don't go there.
I said let me send Danny down to get you.
Let me just send him. It's fine up here.
You know, let me send him down to get you.
Please, you know, come on up."
And she's like, "You know, no, I'll be fine.
I'll be fine." And then about five minutes later, I get a text,
"You need to get out of your house.
Your mountain is on fire."
[NARRATOR 2]: Yeah. That's when we saw it.
[INTERVIEWER]: And who'd that text come from?
[NARRATOR 1 and 2]: Martha Clabo.
[NARRATOR 1]: She's another third grade teacher and fine friends.
[NARRATOR 2]: We were trying to get her up the mountain for safety,
but we didn't know it was coming our way.
[NARRATOR 1]: It was chaotic. I mean,
when you look down from where we lived,
you could literally see the glow in the distance.
At that point, you could see the smoke below us.
So it was more of, less of seeing fire and more of seeing just this red, orange-y glow.
And when the wind would kick up,
that glow would get really bright.
[NARRATOR 2]: That's when you, I realized that we kind of underestimated how quickly a fire will spread.
As we were thinking, no way.
[NARRATOR 1]: Because it was on the other side, right.
[NARRATOR 2]: Yeah, it was way, you know, it was not even into Gatlinburg.
You're hearing things, but it moved out of the mountains, the
national park, right up through,
you know, I guess it jumped over River Road in
the main street there and then just climbed up Chalet Village.
But yeah, it was real when you could see the flames
below us and then you started... It was dark.
She's starting to load the car up.
She's smart enough to remember Madison's and...
[NARRATOR 1]: The cat.
[NARRATOR 2]: ...the cat.
[NARRATOR 1]: The child.
[NARRATOR 2]: Her father was staying with this and he was,
I guess at that point, early stages of dementia.
So that was another challenge we had that evening was her father who's now passed,
but then we had the son.
Our son was with us.
And then the horns were blowing,
we kept hearing yelling,
"Get out." "Evacuate now."
And it's when it all set in it's like, "Okay,
it's probably the water hose is not going to work at this point.
Let's probably get out here."
[NARRATOR 1]: I think that turning point when we felt that we probably needed to leave,
after I got that text from Martha, and she said you need to get down off your mountain.
I looked off the back deck and literally saw an ember float through the air.
And as it landed, it ignited.
And, and then I looked down on Buckberry Lodge and several of the buildings there were engulfed.
[NARRATOR 2]: They where full, yeah.
[NARRATOR 1]: And I thought, that's right. We have to drive past that, you know.
That's really close.
That's not that far away.
And I thought, "We need to go," and that's when I started,
I ran downstairs, got Pearson.
And I said, "We need to leave, sweetheart."
And I said, "Why don't you go upstairs?
I'll grab a few things."
We were still kind of calm, nobody was panicking, and I said you know, just in my head,
I'm thinking, "I'm just going to get a couple things together,
just in case we've already lost power,
wouldn't be a bad idea to leave anyways,
because obviously, power's not going to come back on for a while."
Being though we have gone through hurricanes,
It takes couple days, a week, whatever.
So I thought, "You know, we'll get some things together and we'll get back it.
We'll just drive off into Knoxville, it will be fine."
Had no clue what was transpiring down below the mountain.
Daddy was sleeping.
So I went in there and I woke him up gently I said,
"Daddy, we're going to have to leave.
The fire is getting close and we've lost power,"
and he panicked because he did have, like I said,
he did have dementia and he just, he got up and I calmed him down.
And I said, "It's okay.
We're just going to take our time."
And the cat was at every vent just acting really strange.
Poor Padma, I thought, she was panicking and she didn't like to be picked up.
So we decided we're going to go.
I got my car, pulled it up,
put Pearson in the car,
put Daddy in the car, went back.
Padma is sitting at the front door like,
"I'm ready for you now," a cat that does not like to get picked up,
I picked her up,
she stuck her head in my hoodie.
[NARRATOR 2]: Had that sense that she needed to get out.
[NARRATOR 1]: Yeah. Literally, I mean-
[NARRATOR 2]: Smarter than I was, actually.
[NARRATOR 1]: You know, I put the cat in the car,
I come back and he said,
"Well, why don't you guys go?"
I said, "No, we are all going."
He says, "Well, what should I get?"
I said, "Grab your guitar." So he did.
[NARRATOR 2]: That was it.
[NARRATOR 1]: I followed him down,
we turned right going towards Wiley Oakley, and...
[NARRATOR 2]: We took the bypass. We were trying to get to the bypass,
that was the quicker, that's the quickest route down from where we were living.
But we got halfway down,
I guess Wiley Oakley and a tree had fallen across the road.
[NARRATOR 1]: I think we were still at Upper Alpine at that time.
[NARRATOR 2]: Yeah, I was in front at that point and then couldn't go any further,
it was just a tree had fallen,
it was completely in flames, and
you look to your right and you saw some friends of ours,
the Webster's house, was completely in flames.
[INTERVIEWER]: How did you feel at that point?
What was going through your head?
[NARRATOR 1]: Well, with a tree in front,
the gentleman had come yelling, you know,
"It's time to evacuate."
And we, when we saw that tree, when I saw that tree in front of Danny's car,
I thought, "Oh gosh, we're blocked."
Because they sent us this way.
If they sent us this way,
there's only one other way that I know that's not in flames.
[NARRATOR 2]: It's down Ski Mountain which was already, had to be already on fire.
If we were already on fire where we were at, but it was...
I, we, I got out of the car,
she got out of the car... [NARRATOR 1]: Oh, that was weird. [NARRATOR 2]: ...trying to decide,
okay we need to turn around.
And it was, you know, if you're sitting in your living room and you're just watching the fire crackle,
it was the most peaceful,
it was beautiful actually. Quiet, serene.
[NARRATOR 1]: This is so odd that we're telling you this.
[NARRATOR 2]: Yeah, but it was beautiful,
it was just a nice soft crackle.
[NARRATOR 1]: And it was warm.
[NARRATOR 2]: But then you see your neighbors homes on fire, which is unsettling.
But in those roads, or as you know,
are windy and they're narrow up there at the very top.
So I got, we're back in the car and turned around and I got hung up
on someone's drive way and it had a company vehicle, so,
but I accelerated, you hear the crunching and
the grinding of the under carriage of the car.
[NARRATOR 1]: The removal of the undercarriage. [NARRATOR 2]: But I got turned around.
And at that point, she had already turned around before me,
so she was leading.
Then as we cut back through Lower Alpine back to Ski Mountain.
At that point, it was like there was a caravan.
There was five or six other cars that had come there behind.
[NARRATOR 1]: I think there were a total of seven of us, one behind the other.
[NARRATOR 2]: We kind of said, "You can't go that way,
you got to go back towards Ski Mountain and we just
have to figure out how to get back down the mountain."
And then as soon as we turn left down Ski Mountain,
it was just fire on both sides of the road.
[NARRATOR 1]: Yes, then the right-hand side there,
there were some condos.
[NARRATOR 2]: Already inflamed.
[NARRATOR 1]: You could see the fire coming up the left side of the road,
and you could see that the condos were on fire already.
And I thought, "Okay, just keep driving, the road is still clear."
[NARRATOR 2]: But there were tree stumps,
telephone poles, they were all on fire. [NARRATOR 1]: Everything.
[NARRATOR 2]: It was random what was in flames.
But then you had the dark smoke.
We knew the roads very well and of course,
she was leading the pack at that point.
And I couldn't even tell how many people were behind us,
but I just kind of followed her.
At that point, she had her father in the car, he was screaming.
[NARRATOR 1]: Well, when we got past that condo, it kind of cleared up.
So I thought, "Oh, yay, this is good."
You know, there's no more...the fire is probably just, you know, one little spot.
And we came down the bottom of Ski Mountain
and there's like an area where you drop off your trash.
We pass that and I thought,
"Okay, good. This is great."
And then about, we got to the market, not the market, the restaurant Ski Mountain Pizza.
And it was apparent that point that I thought, either this is going to be...
I didn't have time to be really afraid just to make a decision.
I knew we couldn't go the other way,
so I thought the only thing I can do is keep driving until something gets in my way.
So drove closer and the smoke was so
thick that if this was my, the right side of my car where the headlight was,
I could barely see.
There was a, the, what do they call them?
Not a barricade, what do they call that?
[NARRATOR 2]: Guard rail.
[NARRATOR 1]: A guard rail. And I could see the guard rail about that far
away from the front of my car and that's all I could see.
And there was fire pretty much just encircling the car and the smoke was really thick.
And there was a building on the right that was just roaring,
you could hear that roar of that fire.
And you could feel it on your, your face felt like it was just, I mean, like you were getting a bad sunburn.
[NARRATOR 2]: My temperature gauge on my car, I happened to glance down on it because
you could feel the heat radiating on both sides of your face through the fire.
I think it had said 118 at that point.
So and of course, we're moving through it pretty quick at that point,
but you could just, you felt like just the sun was just like.
[NARRATOR 1]: It was that point that my dad,
who was very afraid, you know, he verbalized that.
I was in a mood,
so I said, "Daddy, don't worry."
I said, "I'm like Mario Andretti,
I can get us through this.
Watch me drive this thing."
You know, and I was being all cocky,
and I did from memory because I drove that road every day to school.
I just stayed steady and prayed nothing had fallen in
the road that I wouldn't be able to see and we kept going.
And as the smoke kind of cleared up a little bit, and I came through that smoke,
there were firetrucks down there, and there was a fireman standing there.
And he looked up and he saw these cars coming out of that smoke.
And I'm not going to verbalize what he said... [NARRATOR 2]: It wasn't a good word.
[NARRATOR 1]: ...but it was along the lines of "Holy Moly,
where are you coming from?"
[NARRATOR 2]: They didn't think there was anybody left up there.
[NARRATOR 1]: Yeah.
[NARRATOR 2]: And as this caravan of cars come down off the mountain.
[NARRATOR 1]: The shock on his face.
[NARRATOR 2]: He had this look on his face like, "Oh, my goodness."
[NARRATOR 1]: "Oh, my gosh," you know.
[NARRATOR 2]: I'm not going to verbalize what he said,
but you could, you could read lips and determine that it wasn't a good word.
[NARRATOR 1]: He was, nonetheless, he was shocked.
[NARRATOR 2]: So it, that was bad enough.
But then when you take a left on River Road,
we didn't go Main Street at that point.
We get down towards the aquarium and we see a police officer.
[NARRATOR 1]: Yes, she was actually, she helps out with the traffic detail at our school in the mornings.
[NARRATOR 2]: And we roll windows down and say,
"What's the best way to her get out?"
She said, "I don't know."
[NARRATOR 1]: She says, "I believe that they've closed the spur and let me find out for you."
And about seconds later, she turned to me and she said "You're
going to have to go out 321 towards Cosby,
that's the only evacuation route right now."
And so we started driving that way.
And you could see again, once again, that community.
There were people in pickup trucks that were literally just anyone who didn't have a car,
they were like... [NARRATOR 2]: Loadin' em up. [NARRATOR 1]: "Just get in." People
were jumping onto trucks.
[NARRATOR 2]: As you go up 321, all of the grates on the side of the road,
flames were coming out of the side of the road. It was really...
[INTERVIEWER]: So you hadn't made it past, through the fire yet?
[NARRATOR 2]: Yeah, you can look up towards the chair lift off
River Road and the old hotels that were right there on River Road...
[NARRATOR 1]: Everything. [NARRATOR 2]: That's where it looked like lava running up the mountain.
You could see the fire going up the hill.
[NARRATOR 1]: Have you ever seen the Tolkien movies with Mordor,
with the lava flowing.
And for like a brief second looking up that mountain, I thought,
"That looks like lava,
it doesn't look like flames."
It looks literally like just streams of lava, it was incredible, you know.
And just thinking we knew all the back roads.
So I'm like, "Oh, we're going to go this way." You'd go down a road...
[NARRATOR 2]: Tree was down, couldn't get out. [NARRATOR 1]: Blocked.
[NARRATOR 2]: We knew all the back ways but all of them were, you couldn't get out.
So we ended up going back towards The Glades.
[NARRATOR 1]: And you could see literally,
if, in your rear view mirrors, you look back.
It just looked like a glowing city.
Just a flame.
[INTERVIEWER]: So where do you evacuate to? To Cosby?
[NARRATOR 1]: Well, we ended up going through The Glades.
And at that point, it started raining.
And of course, you're thanking God.
Like, "This is what we need."
Yes, just pour.
[NARRATOR 2]: Rain was nice.
[NARRATOR 1]: Yeah, and...
[NARRATOR 2]: But you could still see the flames off behind you,
over to your right.
And then they had actually jumped over
into close to Dollywood at that point, Parrot Mountain.
So there, we're sitting, we actually sit for an hour while they
evacuate everybody from Parrot Mountain that we're all in those cabins up there.
So you're sitting in the car.
And of course, your phone is ringing,
people are checking on you.
It's all over the news and all over the country at that point.
So I'm getting phone calls from everywhere and people saying, "You
okay?" "Yeah, I'm fine right now."
But you see the flames like everywhere,
all three sides of us at that point, but you know we...
[NARRATOR 1]: Our families were obviously terrified for us.
And incredibly, our cell phones at that point were still working,
which is the strangest thing.
And just everyone, "Are you okay?" "Are you okay?"
And obvious from seeing our neighbor's home on fire,
I called her and I asked her if they were okay.
And she says "Yes, we've evacuated,
we are at so-and-so's house."
And we ended up driving all the way to Knoxville,
Fountain City, to his mom's house.
And I think we started out at about eight o'clock and got to her house at two in the morning.
[NARRATOR 2]: Two in the morning, that's how long it took us to get out of there.
Interesting thing is once we get to Sevierville,
you see all the caravans of firetrucks and emergency vehicles.
So it was really touching to see all the pouring of emergency help coming.
We saw Greenville, I mean, you started seeing firetrucks...
I guess they dispatch from Kentucky.
I mean you are seeing firetrucks from everywhere.
Found out later there were fire groups that came all the way across from California,
Really, kind of, it's heartfelt to see all those, you know, people that rushed up there.
[INTERVIEWER]: When you get to your mother's house... [NARRATOR 2]: We reeked.
[INTERVIEWER]: ...what are you thinking about?
[NARRATOR 1]: Tears, lots of tears.
[NARRATOR 2]: Yeah, we didn't know if we had a home.
We didn't know we had a home,
we were watching the news,
it's all over the news at that point.
My mother said, "Change."
So we smelled like smoke.
I mean, we've been driving through smoke and fire.
We put everything in the laundry.
[NARRATOR 1]: Our cars.
The inside of the car. Oh my gosh.
I think to this day, barbecues are probably not my favorite thing anymore.
That was an awful smell.
And you thought we had the air on in the car,
so you didn't really notice it that much.
But yeah, I ended up having to have, like, the cabin filter on
the cars replaced and
the whole car detailed and hoses that were compromised had to be replaced.
And yeah, she greeted us at her door and said, ''You all stink,
go and shower.'' And so her little tiny home became our home for the next couple of days.
[NARRATOR 2]: Didn't really had home for about three days.
[INTERVIEWER]: Is it when you went back to Gatlinburg for the first time, three days?
[NARRATOR 1 and 2]: Nine days.
[NARRATOR 2]: But we, she knew people, so we were actually after about the third day watching the news.
[NARRATOR 1]: No, it was Tuesday. We were watching the news.
[NARRATOR 2]: It was a few days after.
Trying to remember the reporters said.
Talking to somebody from the TBI or whatever and said that...
[NARRATOR 1]: Like a drone or helicopter or something. [NARRATOR 2]: ...everything on Upper Alpine is burned. Everything.
But they were showing a scene of, it wasn't Upper Alpine. So they said the road,
but it wasn't a picture of the roads.
I'm still have some skepticism about whether it did burned or not but.
[NARRATOR 1]: I couldn't tell the difference.
Because I thought if it's burned,
how would you know what was there previously from a helicopter? For me, it wouldn't look...
[NARRATOR 2]: We thought our home was burned at that point,
once we heard it on the news and they mentioned that
absolute the street we lived on and everything was gone.
So it's like well, okay. You don't know what to think at that point. What are you going to do?
[NARRATOR 1]: Well, in the spirit of checking on other people.
I had a friend that I knew lived on the street above us,
and I texted her to see how she was doing.
And I said, "I don't know if you've heard,
but our home is gone.
And I just wanted to see how you guys were doing."
She says the National Guard came in and the next day and took us up to Ober.
[NARRATOR 2]: They stayed the night. They were there all night.
[NARRATOR 1]: She said, "We drove by your home and it's still there."
[NARRATOR 2]: So misinformation was flying around everywhere at that point.
[NARRATOR 1]: I said, "Are you kidding me?"
I said, "No, certainly not."
She said, "No, I saw your home."
Then another friend of mine,
he was the SRO at the school, Officer Myers.
He texted me and he said, "Hey, what's your address?"
I have access.
I'll go up and check.
And Thursday morning 6:00 AM,
I get a text.
And he says, "You have a home."
He goes, "You're going to have to clear a path to it,
but you have a home,
it didn't burn down."
He says, I don't know what the backside of your house because
the backside of our house was not accessible.
He says, "I don't know about the backside,
but the front side of your home is there.
You have a bunch of branches and stuff in your driveway, but it's there,
And other than your freezer probably smelling like something or someone has died in it,
you have a house."
[INTERVIEWER]: I guess at some point you move to a hotel or for a few days?
[NARRATOR 2]: We were very blessed.
And I have an aunt who has a beautiful cabin in Townsend and it wasn't affected by the fire.
She called and said, "Look,
I just close on this place,
it's furnished. You guys interested?"
So in my mother's place is just a small little house in Fountain City,
so we needed the room.
So we accepted graciously.
Interesting part of that was her son was in Florida,
had called to say, "Can I come home?"
So, because that was the night of the fire,
she gets a phone call that says, "I need to come
home," and we're like, she said, "Okay, come on.
But we're not sure we have a house at this point."
[NARRATOR 1]: And I put my dad on a plane back to Florida.
I think that was probably best for him.
So we were able to go and stay.
[NARRATOR 2]: My aunt's house in Townsend,
which was really nice.
So we were very fortunate compared to so many other people out there that lost
homes and, you know, lives and we were very blessed.
[NARRATOR 1]: At that point, I think it was Friday that we actually relocated to the cabin.
And the school had to make
decisions as to what we were going to
do because we were in the middle of the school year, so
that's when the decision was made that we would
relocate the school to the Pittman Center old elementary school.
And we met at the high school there to kind of discuss all of that.
Obviously, that was a tearful reunion because we didn't, you didn't know how people are affected.
You hear the rumors, you see on TV.
People were walking around with cell phones,
with pictures on them.
[NARRATOR 2]: Our church. It was our first... We were able, they had church at the high school.
So hat was the other difficult part was when we first
started gathering with people, our church family.
So Larry, who was our pastor,
as we all get together,
you're finding out who lost their homes.
So we're literally standing there. Are you okay?
My home burned. Of course, you know
you're sitting there before church starts.
Just, you know, what do you say to somebody that everything they own burns?
So, I mean that was, and we had, oh my goodness, how many conversations with people that were really close to us that lost their homes.
Then you'd have to say, no we're good, our house is fine.
We found out it's still there and so you get a little bit of guilt there.
But as we're sitting there for church and there's the service starts.
Larry said before we start,
we have some gentlemen from TBI that want to come around.
And so it was very sobering as you're sitting
there and people they're walking around with cell phones.
Have you seen this person?
And you're like, oh my goodness, there's still a lot of people up here they haven't found
yet or identified or trying to find them.
So that was, that was a very sobering moment for us,
was our first gathering back at church,
but we still couldn't get into Gatlinburg proper at that point.
[NARRATOR 1]: Yeah we were able to go, the high school is on 321,
so you can access it through The Glades.
But further, obviously, that leads you into Gatlinburg,
and they had stopping points.
You know, the sheriff's department, the police department,
they were all there, you know,
monitoring and not letting people back in
because one is there was no electricity, no water.
The pump on the mountain that we lived on literally burned up,
so they weren't able to get water up that way.
And but again, the surprising thing of all of this was
the willingness of the people who had
to take care of the people who didn't have at that point.
[NARRATOR 2]: So the community got together, but on the fringe.
They were either going to school at the old elementary school.
You know, church was held at the high school.
So I think for nine days,
we couldn't even get to our house.
[NARRATOR 1]: I learned a lot more about country roads.
[NARRATOR 2]: Then after nine days, they finally gave the release and said come back.
My father had a place up there,
so I picked my father up and we, she was, I think you were at school that day, teaching that day,
but we went on up, and he had a place on Baskins Creek,
and that's the first place we stopped and it was gone.
All that was left was coils from his appliances.
I mean, everything else was dust.
It just burned to the ground.
Everything on that whole strip of Baskins Creek had vanished.
So that was tough watching my father, you know.
It was a weekend place for him,
but it still meant something to him.
So then we'd drove on up the mountain and check on our home
and it was, the only thing I can say is we pulled down the driveway,
it's like, goodness, I'm glad it's here.
The other part, it took us about 10 minutes to get to the front door because
all the tree limbs that had fallen down from the winds that blow over the mountain.
[NARRATOR 1]: I wasn't there at that time,
it was just you, dad, and Pearson, I think.
[NARRATOR 2]: It took us a bit to get in the house, and that gave me another perspective.
We were up there for the winds.
We evacuated that night,
but I guess, just I'd never seen...we have a little walkway that goes to the front door,
a deck like walkway,
and it took us about 10 minutes to get through it because of the tree limbs and everything.
But once we did, the house was fine.
And it smelled a little smokey.
But again, we were very blessed compared to other families.
[NARRATOR 1]: Yeah. I think the fact that we had lost electricity,
there was no intake of smoke.
So upon coming back home, you know,
you walked in and it was like you left it because no one thought to turn off the TV,
or any of the appliances, or any of the, you know,
when the power went off,
it was off until it came back on,
so you didn't walk around flipping switches off.
So you walked in the home,
the heater's on, it's warm, the TV is on.
[NARRATOR 2]: One of the televisions, yeah one of the televisions was still on, we laughed.
It was on, I guess when the power went out.
[NARRATOR 1]: So I thought, oh okay. Welcome home.
[NARRATOR 2]: Yeah.
[NARRATOR 1]: But prior to that,
I traveled from Townsend to Pittman Center because we
started school back and we conducted it there and that was a little surreal.
You, we had trouble getting kids to focus,
as you can imagine.
It's a smaller school, so certain,
like the third grade, we had four third grade classes.
So we paired up two and two in rooms next to each other.
And we would co-teach as much as we could.
Lessons were difficult because you had children that were hurting.
[INTERVIEWER]: How did you start that first day back to school?
What was it like bringing all the kids back together?
[NARRATOR 1]: That's difficult. I was so happy to see the kids,
as were all of the teachers,
and you literally had like one child on this knee and
one child on this knee and just hugging because they were happy you were there.
You were happy that they were there. And that's all we did.
We brought a friend of mine and teacher, Sarah, brought towels.
Her family, her husband's family has cabins that they rent out,
so she brought baskets of towels.
And another teacher, Martha, had Beanie Babies that her son had collected and brought in,
I don't know, oodles of Beanie Babies.
[NARRATOR 2]: A lot of them had not slept.
Some of them had been in the shelter for a long time and just weren't getting any sleep, so I think...
[NARRATOR 1]: His mother donated, because it was Christmas time now,
gave us all these Christmas trees.
So we put up a forest of Christmas trees with lights and all the kids put their towels on
the ground and they had their Beanie Babies and they slept. And they slept. They slept.
[INTERVIEWER]: Well, I'll move just a little bit broader in time just as a reflection now.
You've gotten through the fire,
you've come back to Gatlinburg,
you've seen your home,
and at some point,
you decide to move.
Can you tell me about that decision and
what it was like making that decision and moving to Knoxville?
[NARRATOR 2]: Yeah, that was a tough one just because we loved it up there.
Living there has its challenges,
a tremendous amount of tourism and the tourists,
and people were coming back in droves after the fire.
Just curiosity.
But the only thing I can say,
and maybe this sounds terrible,
all the people that lost places,
money started flowing with insurance checks, I guess.
We were getting phone calls.
I had to travel to the airport every other week or so,
which is about an hour and 20 minutes from where we lived.
So we thought it might have been a good opportunity.
There were people that were looking to replenish their rental properties,
You couldn't get, and talking to some of the people that were
on rental properties up there that may live and doing it,
you couldn't get contractors quick enough.
There was so many people trying to rebuild.
People were just, whatever was left,
they wanted to buy.
So we had a nice offer on our house and we decided to sell and move to Knoxville.
We still have some very close friends up there.
[NARRATOR 1]: It's still home.
[NARRATOR 2]: Yeah.
I feel anytime I go there,
I can literally just text someone on the way and say,
"Hey, I'm coming, you want to meet?" You know.
It's not that far.
So we still have friends from there that visit us here.
I don't feel like I've truly left,
but it'll always be our home.
[INTERVIEWER]: How has this experience, like, impacted you emotionally as a family and as individuals?
[NARRATOR 1]: Initially, it didn't, and I'll speak for myself.
Initially, I felt like I didn't have time to be afraid.
And you get into like maybe a survival mode,
if you may, and made it through it,
did what we had to.
Obviously, it was very tiring.
But looking back on it and talking it,
when I was there,
it didn't seem to be such a tearful event.
Looking back upon it now,
and seeing what people had to go through,
I guess I have time now,
and so it's a little more difficult now.
[NARRATOR 2]: Coming off the mountain that night,
you didn't really realize what you were going through.
I think it is just a matter of, to her point,
we got something to do,
let's just get through this, and we did it.
We didn't think much about it.
I don't think anybody was experiencing any type of,
other than her father,
which he had for understandably, had some issues.
But even our little guy,
I think he was sitting in the backseat petting the cat,
trying to keep the cat calm.
[NARRATOR 1]: That kid's remarkable.
[NARRATOR 2]: Yeah he's, but you know, he also, what troubled us about or concerned us more was,
he had friends who lost their homes.
And, but he was really, a lot of the kids up there, what was really nice to see is how
the children themselves were taking care of each other.
I saw it at the church, she saw it at the school.
But you didn't think about what you're going through at the time.
You see these videos of people driving through wildfires and then it's like...
[NARRATOR 1]: Yeah, that was us.
[NARRATOR 2]: That was us.
We just didn't have the wherewithal to think about recording it.
Sometimes, I look back and say,
that would have been cool to capture that.
We had a picture or two that people sent us.
I think there was a car behind us that took a picture.
[NARRATOR 1]: That sent us a picture of my car.
[NARRATOR 2]: When we got hung up and we were stuck.
[NARRATOR 1]: That looked a lot worse on that picture than I recalled it, you know.
Like he said, when we stepped out of that car,
you were like, this is weird. This is nice, you know.
[NARRATOR 2]: But to talk about it now is what's, I guess, you know, you really at the time don't think it was really a big deal.
But I think it, I mean, we've been asked to speak about it at our church classes multiple times,
just, and it's amazing to see the emotions that people have when you talk about it.
But at the time, we didn't think it was any big deal.
We just were like, okay,
we got something to do. Let's get out of here.
[NARRATOR 1]: For a while after,
I will say that anytime the wind kicked up,
it just kind of, I don't want to say that I was fearful,
but it made you kind of take a breath and go,
oh, well, what's going on?
You know, and that's kind of waned now.
But initially,
anytime the wind kicked up,
it's what came to my mind first.
[NARRATOR 2]: But you see so much of it now, floods in Houston,
I think this week, hurricanes, Puerto Rico.
Well, I mean, the Caribbean this past week or two. You get...
And we've been through hurricanes, you know,
but when you go through something like the fires were pretty devastating,
where people lost lives and homes,
you get a sense of kind of what you're going through.
What you're having to deal with.
[NARRATOR 1]: I think we're more empathetic.
[NARRATOR 2]: Yeah, empathy is certainly something that I think both of us have gained.
Far more empathy than we had prior to that,
which is not a bad thing.
[INTERVIEWER]: Have you ever thought about,
hopefully this would never happen,
but making provisions for a disaster at some point in the future.
Have you about that possibility?
[NARRATOR 1]: Coming from Florida, that was a way of life.
When I moved to Tennessee,
I didn't think that that would be a thing that I had to do.
The area that we live in now is wooded and reminds me a lot of the mountains,
but now I can't say that.
[NARRATOR 2]: I think both of us, we've talked about this,
and both of us have enough -
[NARRATOR 1]: Experience?
[NARRATOR 2]: - I'll say spiritual growth. Yeah, it bothers me.
But the prepper stuff,
I have trouble with that.
You know, if its your time its your time,
so I don't think about that.
Really we don't. We don't prepare that way.
[NARRATOR 1]: Not that I'm interviewing you,
but do you feel like though,
that we appreciate things a little more,
our time together? I feel like we do.
[NARRATOR 2]: Yeah, you hug your kid closer.
You think about families that weren't able to do that anymore.
Yeah, so yeah, I mean, that's where's the empathy comes in.
But do I think about, you know, we would just, if it happens, we would figure out how to get through it.
Again, I think we were very fortunate and blessed in the whole process.
[NARRATOR 1]: I told you before, I feel like Gatlinburg is my home.
I feel that the people there are,
they're survivors.
You know, they're from Appalachians.
[NARRATOR 2]: That character came through a lot up there,
particularly some of the older families that have been there, that lost,
Some of them lost, most of them, a lot of them lost their homes.
Some of the old families up there,
yet they had no ill will towards anything.
Certainly, we were part of some conversations
about how that fire started with the young boys,
and everybody we talked to were like, "Oh, come on.
They were kids. You know, they wanted nothing other than get on with life.
They didn't want any ill to anybody,"
and that was another thing that was like, that kind of set, you know, in my heart was to watch some of those people.
There was no resentment towards anything that we saw,
and the people that seem to want to stir it up,
I don't think they were from up there.
[NARRATOR 1]: That's true.
And look at it now. [NARRATOR 2]: None of the circles we ran through.
[NARRATOR 1]: They've gotten so many, the SkyBridge now and you know, they've rebuilt the chair lift.
And I had the opportunity to do that with a friend of mine like, you know, just recently,
you know, they just, and it's almost like they fell down,
rolled, got back up,
and kept moving. That's an amazing community.
[NARRATOR 2]: It speaks to the character
of a lot of the people that come out of those mountains up there,
which is really East Tennessee as a whole.
You know, it's strong.
They're strong people up there. That's what...
[NARRATOR 1]" You watched as people rebuilt their lives on
Facebook, you know, and just appreciate what they had to go through.
You know, the people that chose to stay,
gosh, I admire them so much,
that had to rebuild our home from scratch in the same location,
and watching as plants that had burned to
the ground reseeded and started popping up and reminding them of their own.
[NARRATOR 2]: We were up there after, the next spring.
So you started seeing the growth just in the plants and trees,
everything coming up in the underbrush.
So we were there long enough after the fires to see the rebirth,
at least from the nature side of it.
But then we also saw the rebirth and it's like how everybody said,
all right, we got stuff,
we got to get back on track.
[NARRATOR 1]: So on reflection, I feel like it was a terrible thing.
But thankfully, the group of people that had to endure it,
that they were the one who endured it because they have just
bounced back and really had made something of it,
and I'm grateful that you guys are recording this.
[INTERVIEWER]: Well, we're grateful to you.
It's been wonderful hearing your story and so inspirational too.
Is there anything else that we haven't talked about that you might want to
say on record before we end today's interview?
[NARRATOR 1]: We love our Gatlinburg family,
and again, it will always be home.
[INTERVIEWER]: Thank you so much.
[NARRATOR 1]: You're welcome.
